Comment:
Completely agree,
Burn is not just about numbers, it reflects mindset. 
At Urban Umamii, we‚Äôve built a culture of frugality and discipline: testing 25,000+ samples, setting up kiosks in high-footfall areas without rent, and keeping raw material cost at ~28%. This foundation ensures every rupee works hard for us.

Companies that solve challenges through spending often avoid the harder work of systems thinking. When resources are constrained, teams get creative about solutions rather than throwing budget at symptoms. The 'weak engine, more fuel, bigger fire'  perfectly captures why so many well-funded startups implode. Smart investors know this - they're not just funding growth, they're funding decision-making patterns that will define the company forever. What early cultural signals do you, Rishabh Mariwala look for that predict long-term capital efficiency?

Headline: Co-founder at The Indus Valley with expertise in product development, operations and supply chain.
Comment:
Capital efficiency forces us to build reliable structures and processes early on.

It makes us spend more time understanding what the customer really needs. That is what drives better product market fit.

It makes us fight for that extra 0.5% on a contract that will eventually shape the bottom line.

As founders, when we live and breathe capital efficiency, the team follows.
It becomes the culture. It becomes normal. This is how we drive The Indus Valley and manage to have a capital efficiency of 4.5

It's been a long journey, we have a longer way to go. But our core is made the sustainable way.
